awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Two-Dimensional Substrates to Study and Control the Atomic-Scale Structure of Metal Nanoclusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Non Technical Summary 

Nanoscale clusters (NCs) containing a finite number of metal atoms and attached to the surfaces of support materials play a pivotal role for applications in energy technologies.  Two-dimensional substrates offer a unique platform to study NCs owing to their large and well-defined surfaces with no dangling bonds, and minimal scattering of electrons, which allows for imaging of NCs with atomic resolution. The goal of this research is to employ a self-consistent, combined theoretical and experimental approach to study supported metal NCs, and how these adapt by substrate variations. The theoretical calculations are based on classical and quantum theories in conjunction with evolutionary algorithms, while as the experimental approach relies on electron microscopy to determine the structure at the nanoscale. Educationally, the proposed research will serve as an interdisciplinary platform for graduate and undergraduate students to learn about materials discovery at the nanoscale. Given the significant impact that novel materials will have on much of daily life and the national economy, this work will strengthen materials education at the University of Pittsburgh and the University of Illinois at Chicago via developing new course components and novel education modules, as well as conducting outreach activities for pre-college and high school students.


Technical Summary 

The atomic structure of supported sub-nanometer clusters on two-dimensional (2D) substrates is a scientifically challenging and largely unexplored field of study. Upon completion, this work will determine how variations in 2D substrates can impact the atomic structure of supported NCs. The atomic structures are predicted using a genetic algorithm utilizing atomistic force fields and density functional theory, which are then validated using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy. Significantly, correlating experimental results with theoretical predictions will lead to advances in the fundamental understanding of supported metals on 2D substrates that could be the basis for using such substrates as a means to control the structure of the metal clusters at the atomic scale. The proposed research efforts will be further integrated with educational efforts where graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in multidisciplinary research. Dedicated effort and resources will be used to recruit and support underrepresented students (women, African-Americans, Hispanics, and first-generation) in the proposed research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project's outcomes significantly contribute to the fundamental understanding of nanoparticle synthesis and behavior on two-dimensional substrates, with implications for a wide range of applications including catalysis, energy storage, and biomedical technologies. The training of PhD students and the project's dissemination efforts ensure a lasting impact on the scientific community and potentially on commercial and industrial applications. The integration of AI with material science methodologies heralds a new era in materials analysis and development. The project's success in developing novel nanoparticle synthesis methods, understanding their behaviors under various conditions, and exploring their applications in energy and biomedical fields exemplifies its intellectual merit.

 

Training and Professional Development

The project provided extensive training and professional development opportunities, especially for more than 10 PhD students. They received specialized training in advanced microscopy techniques, including aberration-corrected Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) and in-situ Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), essential for cutting-edge materials science research. These students were also involved in the synthesis of multielement materials and gained theoretical knowledge in nucleation and growth theories of metallic nanoparticles. They had the opportunity to publish more than 30 journal paper and present their work at several international conferences, enhancing their communication skills and professional networks​​.

 

Key Accomplishments

1. Synthesis and Analysis of Nanoparticles:

 (+) Development of scalable methods for synthesizing high entropy hydroxide and oxide nanoparticles through electrochemical synthesis​​.

(+) Creation of High-entropy alloy nanoparticles (HEA-NPs) using microwave heating and carbon-based substrates, contributing to catalysis, energy storage, and conversion applications​​.

(+) Discovery of metal oxide supports enhancing the catalytic behavior of low-cost catalysts based on Fe, improving durability and activity​​.

(+) Development of novel catalysts such as dimeric copper centers supported on graphitic carbon nitride for methane partial oxidation​​.

(+) Study of Mo catalyst nanoparticles for effective electrochemical carbon dioxide reduction reactions​​​​.

(+) Investigation of environmental-induced degradation of nanoparticles on 2D substrates and the sintering behavior of Pt and Au-core Pt-shell nanoparticles under various atmospheric conditions​​.

(+) Synthesis and stabilization of single atoms at high temperatures using a controllable high-temperature shockwave method, thus opening new avenues for single-atom manufacturing​​.

(+) Atomic resolution imaging of high entropy alloy nanoparticles used in ammonia catalysis, demonstrating substantially enhanced catalytic activity​​.

(+) Development of a highly efficient cathode catalyst for rechargeable Li–CO2 batteries, involving the implantation of single iron atoms into porous carbon architectures​​.

 2. Integration of Artificial Intelligence with Nanomaterials:

(+) Integration of machine learning with Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) imaging of nanoparticles, facilitating the on-the-fly analysis and broadening the application scope in nanoscience​​.

 3. Understanding Nanoparticle Behaviors:

(+)  Analysis of nucleation and growth dynamics of gold nanoparticles on MoS2 nanoflakes​​.

(+) Investigation of thermal decomposition of metal salt precursors on carbon structures for controlled synthesis of metal-decorated carbon nanomaterials​​.

(+) Study of the formation and evolution of phosphatidylcholine-based liposomes, providing insights into the growth mechanism of these structures​​.

 4. Innovative Materials and Applications:

(+)  Synthesis of high-entropy materials with unique structures for various applications​​.

(+) Exploration of lithium-air batteries based on lithium oxide (Li2O) formation for high energy density comparable to gasoline​​.

(+) Analysis of magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles for biomedical applications like hyperthermia and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) contrast enhancement​​.

(+) Contributions to the understanding of catalyst particles and electrocatalysis, such as the production of propane from CO2​​.

(+) Study of ice nucleation and growth at the nanoscale, important in geological and atmospheric sciences​​.
